articles.headline: Ending Tax Break for Ultrawealthy May Not Take Act of Congress
articles.snippet: Some experts say President Obama could abolish the carried interest tax break, which mostly benefits the top one-tenth of the 1 percent in income.
articles.abstract: Some experts say President Obama could abolish the carried interest tax break, which mostly benefits the top one-tenth of the 1 percent in income.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s only natural that Barack Obama, entering the homestretch of his presidency, would be concerned about his legacy. Judging from a recent interview in The New York Times Magazine, getting credit for the actions he has taken on economic issues seems to be of special interest to him.

articles.headline: In Deeply Divided Chicago, Most Agree: City Is Off Course
articles.snippet: Residents of the nation’s third-largest city, especially blacks and Latinos, have lost faith in many of its essential institutions, a survey finds.
articles.abstract: Residents of the nation’s third-largest city, especially blacks and Latinos, have lost faith in many of its essential institutions, a survey finds.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The people of Chicago are deeply riven by race, class and neighborhood, distrustful of the police, fearful of the growing rate of violent crime and united chiefly in their disapproval of the mayor’s performance and their conviction that the city is headed down the wrong track.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Giovanni Russonello

articles.headline: The Rabbis Are Here to Inspect the (Legal) Weed
articles.snippet: At least two companies, in New York and Illinois, aim to sell kosher medical marijuana products like tinctures and cannabis oil.
articles.abstract: At least two companies, in New York and Illinois, aim to sell kosher medical marijuana products like tinctures and cannabis oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHNSTOWN, N.Y. — The rabbis had never inspected a medical marijuana plant before.

articles.headline: Judge in Sumner Redstone Trial Says He’s Leaning Toward Dismissal
articles.snippet: After watching a video in which the media mogul used obscenities to refer to the former lover who filed the suit, Judge David Cowan suggested he had seen enough.
articles.abstract: After watching a video in which the media mogul used obscenities to refer to the former lover who filed the suit, Judge David Cowan suggested he had seen enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The lawsuit over Sumner M. Redstone’s competency took a startling turn on Friday when the judge interrupted afternoon testimony to say that he was strongly entertaining a motion by Mr. Redstone’s lawyers to dismiss the whole case.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Emily Steel

articles.headline: As North Korea’s Nuclear Program Advances, U.S. Strategy Is Tested
articles.snippet: Efforts to restrain the program have failed to prevent the North from gaining the capability to launch a nuclear attack that could reach much of Japan and South Korea, intelligence officials say.
articles.abstract: Efforts to restrain the program have failed to prevent the North from gaining the capability to launch a nuclear attack that could reach much of Japan and South Korea, intelligence officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — After years of trying to separate fact from propaganda about North Korea’s nuclear program, American and South Korean intelligence officials say they have concluded that the country can now mount a small nuclear warhead on short- and medium-range missiles capable of hitting much of Japan and South Korea.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Treasury Department Rejects Plan to Cut Pension Benefits for Teamsters
articles.snippet: The move was welcomed by workers and retirees, but did not offer a solution for the pension fund, which is on track to go bankrupt in about 10 years.
articles.abstract: The move was welcomed by workers and retirees, but did not offer a solution for the pension fund, which is on track to go bankrupt in about 10 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department on Friday rejected a plan to cut benefits for 270,000 union drivers and retirees who belong to a deeply troubled Teamster pension fund, a decision that could thwart the intentions of other large, financially struggling pension funds.

articles.headline: Raised-Fist Photo by Black Women at West Point Spurs Inquiry
articles.snippet: The military academy has opened an investigation into whether the women violated Army rules that prohibit political activities while in uniform.
articles.abstract: The military academy has opened an investigation into whether the women violated Army rules that prohibit political activities while in uniform.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of young black women poised to graduate from the United States Military Academy gathered on the steps of West Point’s oldest barracks last week in traditional gray dress uniforms, complete with sabers, for a group photo. Known as an “Old Corps” photograph because it mimics historical portraits, it was nearly identical to thousands that cadets have posed for over the decades, with one key difference: The 16 women raised their clenched fists.

articles.headline: An Ayn Rand Acolyte Selling Students a Self-Made Dream
articles.snippet: Carl Barney made millions running for-profit colleges, but he says it’s Rand’s unapologetic vision of unfettered capitalism that has put him on top.
articles.abstract: Carl Barney made millions running for-profit colleges, but he says it’s Rand’s unapologetic vision of unfettered capitalism that has put him on top.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — “I want to be first on Success,” said Carl Barney, standing up from the breakfast table after a final sip of tea at Deer Valley, a luxury resort with a view of Utah’s mountainous rooftop.

articles.headline: Podcasts Surge, but Producers Fear Apple Isn’t Listening
articles.snippet: The podcast has soared in popularity. But there’s not much money in it for Apple, the genre’s creator, leaving many in the community feeling neglected.
articles.abstract: The podcast has soared in popularity. But there’s not much money in it for Apple, the genre’s creator, leaving many in the community feeling neglected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven P. Jobs put his talent as a master salesman to the test when, in 2005, he introduced new Apple software for downloading digital audio shows. The format was so incipient that he struggled to describe it.

articles.headline: Saudi King Shakes Up Government as Economic Plan Moves Forward
articles.snippet: King Salman issued a new wave of royal decrees, replacing a number of top ministers and restructuring government bodies.
articles.abstract: King Salman issued a new wave of royal decrees, replacing a number of top ministers and restructuring government bodies.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Troubled by low oil prices and unsettled by a hostile landscape in the Middle East heightened by a growing rivalry with Iran, Saudi Arabia is moving to chart an ambitious new direction for the kingdom.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Republican Party Unravels Over Donald Trump’s Takeover
articles.snippet: The Republican Party’s crisis over Donald J. Trump reflects years of fraying ties between party elites and voters.
articles.abstract: The Republican Party’s crisis over Donald J. Trump reflects years of fraying ties between party elites and voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: By seizing the Republican presidential nomination for Donald J. Trump on Tuesday night, he and his millions of supporters completed what had seemed unimaginable: a hostile takeover of one of America’s two major political parties.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Seeing President Mugabe’s Frailty, Zimbabwe Braces for Turmoil
articles.snippet: Anxiety and cutthroat politics grip a nation that has known no other leader as Robert Mugabe, 92, shows increasing signs of aging, even talking about his own mortality.
articles.abstract: Anxiety and cutthroat politics grip a nation that has known no other leader as Robert Mugabe, 92, shows increasing signs of aging, even talking about his own mortality.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — The independence festivities took place just as they have for decades: led by President Robert Mugabe, the only leader Zimbabwe has ever had.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Hopewell Chin'ono

articles.headline: Masters of Prose Warm Up to Children’s Picture Books
articles.snippet: Well-known writers like Jane Smiley, Calvin Trillin and Elena Ferrante are turning their talents toward a booming genre, aiming to draw younger readers.
articles.abstract: Well-known writers like Jane Smiley, Calvin Trillin and Elena Ferrante are turning their talents toward a booming genre, aiming to draw younger readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a reading in Manhattan last month, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Jane Smiley faced an unruly crowd as she read from her new book, “Twenty Yawns.” Audience members squirmed and fidgeted, shouted out questions, and seemed to get distracted.

articles.headline: Women’s Rising Influence in Politics, Tinted Green
articles.snippet: Female donors are putting more money into campaigns than they ever have, at every elective level and in both major parties.
articles.abstract: Female donors are putting more money into campaigns than they ever have, at every elective level and in both major parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: Women are bankrolling political campaigns this year more than ever, driven by their rising rank in the workplace, boosts in women’s wealth, and networks set up to gather their donations and bolster their influence.

articles.headline: A Slice of the Confederacy in the Interior of Brazil
articles.snippet: A city in São Paulo State that Americans fled to after the Civil War still celebrates Dixie culture, without dwelling on slavery or the battle flag.
articles.abstract: A city in São Paulo State that Americans fled to after the Civil War still celebrates Dixie culture, without dwelling on slavery or the battle flag.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA BÁRBARA D’OESTE, Brazil — On a stage festooned with Confederate flags, a singer was belting out “Dixieland Delight” by Alabama near an obelisk honoring the Americans who fled to this outpost in the aftermath of the Civil War.

articles.headline: Lawyers in Sumner Redstone Trial Tussle Over Possible Dismissal
articles.snippet: The legal team for the media mogul’s ex-lover argued that his testimony should not be accepted at face value, while his lawyers contended that the case need not proceed.
articles.abstract: The legal team for the media mogul’s ex-lover argued that his testimony should not be accepted at face value, while his lawyers contended that the case need not proceed.
articles.lead_paragraph: A former lover of the ailing media mogul Sumner M. Redstone, who is waging a legal battle over his mental competency, made a last-ditch attempt over the weekend to keep her salacious lawsuit alive.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Warning to Paul Ryan Signals Further G.O.P. Discord
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s refusal to rule out removing Mr. Ryan as the chairman of the party’s convention threatened to upset an event that is normally a display of unity.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s refusal to rule out removing Mr. Ryan as the chairman of the party’s convention threatened to upset an event that is normally a display of unity.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rift in the Republican Party grew deeper on Sunday and threatened to upset the July convention as Donald J. Trump refused to rule out blocking Paul D. Ryan, the speaker of the House, from serving as the convention’s chairman.

articles.headline: Police and Tech Giants Wrangle Over Encryption on Capitol Hill
articles.snippet: Behind-the-scenes lobbying heightens in this next phase of a divide over digital security that erupted when Apple refused to help unlock an iPhone used in a mass shooting.
articles.abstract: Behind-the-scenes lobbying heightens in this next phase of a divide over digital security that erupted when Apple refused to help unlock an iPhone used in a mass shooting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the district attorney of Manhattan, visited Washington late last month to argue his case on a pressing issue: encryption.

articles.headline: Fox’s Sports Network Hires an ESPN Veteran for a Reinvention
articles.snippet: Jamie Horowitz, the ousted executive of the “Today” show, believes that his strategy of opinion-based programming will make FS1 a more serious rival to ESPN.
articles.abstract: Jamie Horowitz, the ousted executive of the “Today” show, believes that his strategy of opinion-based programming will make FS1 a more serious rival to ESPN.
articles.lead_paragraph: When talking about his programming philosophy, Jamie Horowitz, the president of Fox Sports National Networks, fondly cites a quote recently attributed to Norman Lear, the acclaimed creator of “All in the Family.”

articles.headline: U.S. Role in Afghanistan Turns to Combat Again, With a Tragic Error
articles.snippet: Green Berets’ descriptions of a battle with the Taliban in Kunduz, where an airstrike killed 42 people at a hospital, reflected the blurry parameters of the American mission.
articles.abstract: Green Berets’ descriptions of a battle with the Taliban in Kunduz, where an airstrike killed 42 people at a hospital, reflected the blurry parameters of the American mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Taliban attacked the Afghan police compound at first light, coming from all sides at the American Green Berets holed up inside. The insurgents fired assault rifles, heavy machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades. They came in what a soldier called “human waves.”
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Joseph Goldstein

articles.headline: New York Fed Chief Believes the Central Bank Is on the Right Track
articles.snippet: William C. Dudley of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York foresees enough growth for the Fed to resume slowly raising its benchmark interest rate.
articles.abstract: William C. Dudley of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York foresees enough growth for the Fed to resume slowly raising its benchmark interest rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: William C. Dudley, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York president, who helped pilot the Fed’s post-crisis stimulus campaign, sounded pretty calm about the nation’s current economic situation.

articles.headline: Saudi Minister Has Task of Easing Dependence on Oil
articles.snippet: Energy experts do not expect a quick or easy change in policy after the ouster of Ali al-Naimi as minister over the weekend.
articles.abstract: Energy experts do not expect a quick or easy change in policy after the ouster of Ali al-Naimi as minister over the weekend.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — He was known as the “maestro,” the man whose every word was dissected by oil traders and moved markets. For two decades, Saudi Arabia’s oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, was the architect of Saudi and OPEC cartel policies, including the one that has now sent the price of oil into a deep collapse.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Anger Overflows in Nigeria as Economy Dives
articles.snippet: Plummeting oil prices have set off an economic unraveling and collective anger in a country that is among the world’s top oil producers.
articles.abstract: Plummeting oil prices have set off an economic unraveling and collective anger in a country that is among the world’s top oil producers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Young men became entangled in a swirl of flying fists. Gas station workers swatted away boys hoping to fill their plastic cans. A mother with a sleeping baby in her minivan was chased off, rightly accused of jumping the line. A driver eager to get ahead crashed into several cars, the sound of crunching metal barely registering amid the noise.

articles.headline: Countersuits Over North Carolina’s Bias Law
articles.snippet: Gov. Pat McCrory and the Justice Department are clashing over transgender rights after the department said that the state had violated the Civil Rights Act of 1964 with its law on bathroom access.
articles.abstract: Gov. Pat McCrory and the Justice Department are clashing over transgender rights after the department said that the state had violated the Civil Rights Act of 1964 with its law on bathroom access.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — The nation’s clash over the rights of transgender people escalated sharply on Monday as Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina and the Justice Department sued each other, testing the boundaries of federal civil rights laws in a dispute over public restroom access.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder, Richard Pérez-Peña and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: New Orleans Plan: Charter Schools, With a Return to Local Control
articles.snippet: Control of the city’s schools is expected to return to a locally elected school board for the first time since Hurricane Katrina in 2005.
articles.abstract: Control of the city’s schools is expected to return to a locally elected school board for the first time since Hurricane Katrina in 2005.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Nothing has defined and even driven the fractious national debate over education quite like this city and the transformation of its school system in the decade since Hurricane Katrina.

articles.headline: Sumner Redstone Competency Case Abruptly Dismissed by Judge
articles.snippet: A former lover’s challenge to the media titan’s mental competency was rejected by a judge in a case that had drawn wide attention on Wall Street and in Hollywood.
articles.abstract: A former lover’s challenge to the media titan’s mental competency was rejected by a judge in a case that had drawn wide attention on Wall Street and in Hollywood.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The trial over the mental competency of the ailing media mogul Sumner M. Redstone was over almost before it began.
